8.18.text: Greetings, lovelies! Hi, it's Emmy; welcome back!

10.04.text: Today, I'll be eating another military ration, and it is this:

14.52.text: so this is a Japanese Self-Defense Forces Ration Pack.

18.40.text: So this ration pack was graciously sent to me by the kings of military ration pack reviews here on YouTube:

27.08.text: If you guys don't know them already, I'll put the links down in the description box.

29.80.text: but they do all these different kinds of reviews of international military ration packs here on YouTube.

35.00.text: So, be sure to check them out; show them some love;

36.84.text: and, thank you guys so much for sending this to me --

38.40.text: I'm super excited to taste the Japanese military ration packs!

42.54.text: If you've missed my other videos, I've done a couple other ration packs.

45.46.text: I've done two MRE's which are an American version of these ration packs

49.34.text: as well as a UK version, so, be sure to check the links below if you missed those videos.

53.86.text: So, YES! This is super exciting!

55.96.text: So, these are called: "Mili-meshi" which is a combination of "military" and "meshi."

61.78.text: So, this is a Type 2 Mili-meshi and Type 2 is called "Paku Meshi."

66.18.text: "Paku" meaning packs. So, these come in different packs.

69.80.text: And, it includes THIS awesome thing!

73.10.text: I'm so excited to check this out!

74.66.text: It comes with this bag -- this very long bag --

77.46.text: and, it has instructions on how to heat the packs up.

81.80.text: It also comes with this as well; so, this is the chemical pack that you put in here

85.44.text: along with the food and you add some water.

88.84.text: And, then, that will cause a chemical reaction which will heat up the packs

92.60.text: which is similar to the American MREs that have a self-heating unit as well.

96.28.text: So, let's see what's inside this thing!

98.50.text: On the back, it says in English: "Japanese Type 2," and it says "Pork with Amakara sauce."

105.34.text: So Amakara is a combination of "amai" and "karai";

108.62.text: So, "amai, " is sweet, and "karai" can mean salty or spicy.

113.48.text: So, it's like a sweet and salty sauce.

117.60.text: And, the contents feel kind of squishy.

119.70.text: The plastic is kind of thin, and...

123.76.text: almost translucent. You can almost -- the light kind of passes through it.

127.02.text: So, yeah! Let's see what's inside!

128.82.text: It has a little notch, so we can open it this way.

142.08.text: This is the pork and the sauce, and it feels squishy

144.36.text: and I can feel some...chunks inside there.

147.34.text: And then we have two packets of cooked rice.

150.14.text: So, this is just "gohan," which is just rice

152.04.text: and it looks to be already cooked.

153.98.text: I think potentially, you could just eat this cold if you didn't want to heat it up.

158.42.text: I think it would be fine just like this.

160.28.text: And, then it comes with a spork!

161.78.text: Quite a bit shorter than both the UK and the American version in terms of length.

166.56.text: Uh, but, again, very sturdy plastic.

169.04.text: It doesn't look like it will break on you.

173.18.text: So, Gundog, Gshultz9, and Kiwidude also included

176.42.text: three of these packets which are furikake,

179.46.text: and furikake are seaweed-based seasonings that you add to rice.

183.64.text: Super lightweight and adds a ton of flavor to your rice.

186.30.text: It's very common in bentos, so you can liberally just sprinkle this on to your rice

190.36.text: to give it some flavor and taste.

191.98.text: I'm gonna heat these up outside because by the looks of the size of that vent hole,

195.86.text: it looks like it's gonna gas -- offgas a lot...so...

200.42.text: I think it's better to be doing that outside, rather than inside...

203.56.text: All right! So! Let's go do that!

205.22.text: And, I'll let it sit for the requisite 20 minutes and then we'll come back and taste.

210.52.text: Okay, so we're going to open the "morian hito paku,"

214.18.text: and, inside, is the heat pack.

217.50.text: Next, we're gonna take the heat pack and place it at the bottom of the bag.

220.70.text: Then, place the two rice trays and the entree into the bag forming a triangle

227.30.text: Now, using the bag that the heat pack came in too, we're going to fill up the water up to the line

231.86.text: which very cleverly is printed inside and says:

236.64.text: Pour the measured water into the bag and fold over the flap.

240.56.text: And, then, make sure you have something to prop up the bag

243.18.text: and, then allow it to sit for 20 minutes.

250.14.text: Okay, so we're back and it's been 20 minutes

252.38.text: since I've put these ration packs into their heater

259.66.text: So, I was a little bit concerned that the steam and the gases would be trapped in

262.76.text: because of the way the bag was structured

266.30.text: The entire bag and the heating unit stayed inflated for the entire 20 minutes pretty much.

270.68.text: And, uh, yeah, it was super great!

272.10.text: A lot more reactive, I feel, than the US MRE kits where there...it's just much more self-contained.

280.18.text: So let's open one of these rice packs first.

285.54.text: It's like bread here in the States.

289.02.text: So! Great to have some rice!

299.28.text: It looks like a stew -- it's bright orange in color.

302.30.text: And, it smells awesome! I'm just going to pour it over my rice.

311.62.text: Let me get a piece of meat...along with some rice.

322.04.text: It's quite good! It is a little bit spicy.

325.86.text: The pork pieces are actually very, very tender:

328.38.text: they're pork belly pieces, so they're nice and fatty and super tender!

332.94.text: And, it doesn't taste like cafeteria food.

336.64.text: And, it doesn't have a tinned flavor either, because it's in this pack!

341.64.text: and, a little bit spicy, which I find kind of surprising for Japanese food.

345.32.text: The rice is delicious as well -- tender, slightly sticky...

348.60.text: very much the style of Japanese rice.

352.90.text: The sauce is a little bit oily -- a little fatty --

356.94.text: Nice and onion-y, again, with a little bit of soy, and a little bit of spice

361.02.text: which, I'm actually quite surprised by.

363.02.text: In my opinion, much better than any other ration packs that I've had --

366.46.text: both the UK and the US version.

369.32.text: I feel like the food doesn't taste cafeteria-like.

372.14.text: Because it's slightly spicy and so flavorful, I think if you couldn't heat this up in the ration heater

376.36.text: that, it would still taste delicious.

379.86.text: All right, so let's try just the regular rice with a couple of these furikake seasonings as well.

385.40.text: Okay! So, there's the other rice pack

387.88.text: and, let's put the wasabi furikake...

391.84.text: And...we'll put some of that on there...

396.24.text: And we'll put on the aojiso as well.

400.64.text: We'll put that in the middle; that looks very similar to the wasabi.

405.22.text: And then, we'll put the salmon one as well.

407.36.text: So, let's taste the salmon one first.

419.02.text: and fishy and briny, but delicious!

421.18.text: The next one is the aojiso, which is the green shiso leaf.

432.30.text: Shiso has a very unique flavor --

434.38.text: It tastes a little bit anise-y,

438.46.text: That one also had some sesame seeds in it, so it's a little bit toasty

443.36.text: And the last one is the wasabi...

446.04.text: which is translated in English as a Japanese horseradish.

455.14.text: That had some fish flakes in it as well,

459.52.text: so it has a little bit of that nose flaring action...Great!

462.40.text: I think I actually like the salmon one the best

464.58.text: in terms of just having an all-around, really delicious

468.84.text: This rice, I have to say, is wonderful.

471.62.text: For those people out there that eat rice, you guys know that nothing is worse than cold rice.

475.50.text: It has this really hard, terrible, stale texture.

478.60.text: But, because this has been heated so thoroughly, it's nothing like that...

481.94.text: it tastes like fresh, steamed rice!

483.98.text: I am super impressed with that!

486.06.text: So good. And, sticky, and delicious!

490.60.text: So, that was my Japanese Self-Defense Forces Ration Pack tasting,

495.64.text: Thank you guys so much for sending me this packet

498.90.text: not only for its wonderful flavor,

500.36.text: but, I really love the simplicity of it.

502.06.text: All it had was the heater and the dishes

504.24.text: It was really simple and easy to put together.

506.60.text: So, let me know in the comments below if you've ever had a mili-meshi before

509.48.text: or, any kind of ration pack for that matter;

511.40.text: I want to know more -- it's fascinating!

512.90.text: So, yep! Thank you guys so much for watching

514.38.text: I hope you guys enjoyed that,

515.32.text: I hope you guys learned something,

516.64.text: and I shall see you in my next video!
